text:
The Prince Albert Times

Wednesday, January 24, 1853

Our Country.

The fertile plains of the North-West Territories are destined at no distant day to be the greatest wheat producing region in the world. The richness of the soil and the rapidity with which the virgin prairies may be converted into "rolling fields of golden grain," render this the most suitable quarter of the globe to which the industrious people of the overcrowded countries of the Old World can come in order to better their circumstances and reap for themselves and their children that measure of prosperity which is due to those who honestly and perseveringly endeavor to help themselves. To all those who desire, or whom necessity compels to come to a new country, we would say that, while we believe that our soil is the most productive of the known world, we also believe that the actual settlers can obtain it from the Dominion Government and from the C.P.R. Syndicate at rates lower than are charged in any other colonies of the United Kingdom or the United States; and hence, those desirable lands are within the reach of all.

The climate, though cold in winter and very warm in summer, is a most healthy one; and we are fully satisfied that it compares favorably with that of the older provinces of the Dominion, and the extraordinary expressions of praise which emigrants from the United Kingdom bestow on our clear atmosphere and its invigorating qualities, convince us that the clouds, rains and fogs of the British Isles are more objectionable climatic features than our periods of extreme heat and cold.

While much more could be said in favor of our country, we do not wish it to be understood that this is a terrestrial paradise, where fortunes are acquired without labor or hardships of any kind, but we do intend it to be understood that it presents to the industrious and frugal better opportunities to acquire a competence than they can expect to meet elsewhere.

A certain amount of labor must be done, and hardships more or less severe must be undergone in opening up all new countries, but in the North-West Territories the minimum of outlay seems to be demanded with the maximum of income.

In consequence of these facts becoming more widely known, our country is being rapidly settled up, and to those people who are struggling against adverse circumstances in other lands, we say come and receive while you may, as a gift, your share of our prairies, and out of the fruits of your toil provide a rich inheritance for your children in a country where their relief can be subjects them to no hardships; where law and order reign, and happiness and prosperity are the conditions of its peace.

Subscribe for the Times, only $2.50 a year.

STEWART AND WOOTTON,

GOOD WORDS.

The following letter was received by
gentlemen in Prince Albert, from Mr.
Montreal, Canada, 1877:

My Dear Friend,

I lately received two letters, which
were posted to me, and I have no
opportunity of answering them, they are
written in such a high state of excitement,
that you would be doing me a favor to
read them. I am obliged to say that
the contents of both letters are very
interesting, and I shall be glad to
receive your reply.

Yours ever,

[Signature]

THE TORONTO GLOBE.

The Globe, a weekly newspaper, was
founded in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, in
1836. It has been published continuously
since then, making it one of the oldest
newspapers in North America.

MINING MATTERS.

The mining interests of the Lake of the Woods are assuming such proportions that agencies for the purchase and sale of claims are being established. Messrs. D. K. Brown & Co., who have opened what is termed a Mining Bureau, in the Dundas block, in the office under discussion, are well known in mining circles. Mr. Brown is a well-known mining man and the latter an expert in mining matters, and should be approached before they have purchased any. Operations will begin by offering to the public a subdivision of 5000 acres of land in the Wingham Consolidated Gold Mining Company, of which the incorporators are Messrs. A. W. Fink, P. M. N. Rattray, P. J. Burt, and others. The claims, which have a par value of $30, will be floated at $1. To secure registration and guaranteeing of claims, a deposit of two per cent of the selling price, equivalent to $1 per share, has to be paid down, and the remainder paid off in four installments, which will make a few weeks hence. There is considerable inquiry for land for sale. In the last five years, mining interests have been very active, certainly not more than $20,000 will be placed on the market, and at such prices of mining since the discovery by the progress of development the present is the most favorable opportunity of any for securing land. The location of location F 22, gives $1000 per milligram; location F 22 gives $60 per ton, and location F 22 gives $40 per ton. The Consolidated is wholly under Canadian control, and under the able supervision of Mr. H. B. Brown, who has considerable experience as a miner. The Wingham consolidated company has ore on the dump already valued at $100,000 worth, working up to date six times over. The prospect must be brilliant, for the Consolidated mines are only three miles from those of the Kawartha Consolidated, which have been of almost incredible richness. The shares of the Kawartha are quoted today at $100, and the Consolidated at $150 figures, so those of the Consolidated are bound to rise in sympathy, independent of their own merits.

The Bureau is also representative of the Wingham Consolidated in the floating of this new company, and the men buying at the Bureau can alliumtly be guaranteed. Specimens of gold and other precious minerals, from different mining locations referred to, are on display, and those interested in mining are cordially invited to inspect them. The mining interest surrounding these mines in this city has our best wishes for success, Winnipeg Free Press.

THE RETURN OF OUR WIFE.

It was a keen day. She had been away for several days, and the children had gone to the depot to meet her. They chatted away merrily, while she patted their little heads and smiled affectionately.

"How was Mary?" she enquired; when they both looked up breathlessly.

"Yes, she's well," she said, "she has missed us right enough."

"And Harry?"

"He's going to school. Started last week."

"And you?"

"I'm well, too. He's having a busy time. He said he didn't care if you didn't come back for a year."

The young woman laughed.

Grabbing the children with both hands she rushed for the door with I'll get even with you written on her face. Heaven help him!

The Rev. Mr. J. S. Savage, of Bowden, preached a sermon on newspapers. People have been saying, "This world is wider than ever before." An explanation of this, I believe, will be found in the fact that no man who is utterly alone is ever far away that what he does and says can not be regarded as news in safe to day in the community. If he does not do it, or say it, then very soon he will see his name in a newspaper telling all about him, and this, I believe, is it. It is a fact, and this is why the average man fears more than he fears time, more than he hopes for heaven, more than he fears death. But, on the other hand, Mr. Savage blames the newspapers because he thinks they are generous in their praise, and this is why the average man fears more than he fears time, more than he hopes for heaven, more than he fears death.

APPLY AT

"The Times" Office.
THE OLD FARM GATE.

The old farm gate hangswinging down,
And all the trees around it stand,
And all the birds that sing so loud,
And all the flowers that grow in the land.

The old farm gate hangswinging down,
And all the trees around it stand,
And all the birds that sing so loud,
And all the flowers that grow in the land.

PATRICIA KEMBALL.

A NOVEL.

By E. Lynn Linton, author of "Eliza Hartley," "The True History of Joshua Davidson," &c.

CHAPTER VI.—CONCLUDED.

And so, in one thing, however, she was sure—her husband would be faithful. Mr. Hanley thought it ridiculous to think he could ever want to go down before her, or to make any attempt to get back his former position; but he knew that she would never quite forgive him. For the matter of that following, however, and the village went on as usual, and Pritchard and all; so that her absence would have been remarked not by any advantage. But when the news came that Mr. Hanley was gratified Mr. Hanley, it pleased him to see that his brother had been very good, and that his wife had been very good, too; and that he could afford the rivalry on the principle of the death line and the live dog.

The old farm gate hangswinging down,
And all the trees around it stand,
And all the birds that sing so loud,
And all the flowers that grow in the land.
